member.name: T:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.ConfigurationActionBuilder
member.summary: Allows you to build up a set of configuration actions that can be used all at once to configure a new .

remarks.para: Usually when you are building an and you wish to update the registrations in the new scope, you are required to pass in a single lambda configuration action. Sometimes, though, there is a need to perform some logic, or otherwise programmatically register several things into the new lifetime across different calls or in different locations in your application.
This builder allows you to collect a set of configuration actions and use a final method to create a single aggregate action that can be used to finally create the lifetime scope.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.ConfigurationActionBuilder.Build
member.summary: Creates an aggregated action based on the list of actions contained in the builder.
member.returns: A that contains the aggregate set of registered actions that have been added to this builder.

member.name: T:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.MultitenantContainer
member.summary: implementation that provides the ability to register and resolve dependencies in a multitenant environment.

remarks.para: This container implementation modifies the definition of the standard container implementation by returning values that are tenant-specific. For example, resolving a component via will yield a resolution of the dependency for the current tenant, not from a global container/lifetime.

The "current tenant ID" is resolved from an implementation of
that is passed into the container during construction.

Tenant lifetime scopes are immutable, so once they are retrieved, configured, or an item is resolved, that tenant lifetime scope cannot be updated or otherwise changed. This is important since it means you need to configure your defaults and tenant overrides early, in application startup.
If you do not configure a tenant lifetime scope for a tenant but resolve a tenant-specific dependency for that tenant, the lifetime scope will be implicitly created for you.
You may explicitly create and configure a tenant lifetime scope using the method. If you need to perform some logic and build up the configuration for a tenant, you can do that using a .

member.name: F:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.MultitenantContainer.TenantLifetimeScopeTag
member.summary: Marker object-tag for the tenant-level lifetime scope.

member.name: F:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.MultitenantContainer._defaultTenantId
member.summary: Marker object representing the default tenant ID.

member.name: F:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.MultitenantContainer._tenantLifetimeScopes
member.summary: Dictionary containing the set of tenant-specific lifetime scopes. Key is , value is .
member.remarks: Using rather than a generic dictionary because dictionaries aren't threadsafe even with the lock/double-check. Doesn't have to be a synchronized hashtable since we're managing the write operations internally with our own locks.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.MultitenantContainer.BeginLifetimeScope(System.Action{Autofac.ContainerBuilder})
member.summary: Begin a new nested scope for the current tenant, with additional components available to it. Component instances created via the new scope will be disposed along with it.
member.param: Action on a that adds component registations visible only in the new scope.
member.returns: A new lifetime scope.

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to No type to host was provided by the '{0}' for the service '{1}'..

member.name: P:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Properties.Resources.AutofacHostFactory_ServiceHostTypeNotClass
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The '{0}' did not provide a type to be hosted by WCF that was a concrete implementation type. WCF requires a service host to host a class, not an interface. Consider using a reflection-based registration or an expression-based registration where the return value is a class type. The current service type being returned by '{0}' for constructor string '{1}' is '{2}'..

member.name: P:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Properties.Resources.AutofacHostFactory_ServiceNotRegistered
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The service '{0}' configured for WCF is not registered with the Autofac container..

member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Interface type '{0}' is a generic type definition. You may not create WCF dynamic proxies from open generic interfaces..

member.name: P:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Properties.Resources.DynamicProxy_InterfaceTypeToProxyNotInterface
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The type '{0}' cannot be turned into a proxy type for WCF hosting because it is not an interface. Multitenant WCF hosting requires you to implement a separate interface for your service contract..

member.name: P:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Properties.Resources.DynamicProxy_InterfaceTypeToProxyNotPublic
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Interface type '{0}' is not public. It must be accessible so a dynamic proxy object can be created from it..

member.name: P:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Properties.Resources.DynamicProxy_InterfaceTypeToProxyNotServiceContract
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The type '{0}' cannot be turned into a proxy type for WCF hosting because it is not marked with System.ServiceModel.ServiceContractAttribute. Multitenant WCF hosting requires you to implement a separate interface for your service contract..

member.name: P:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Properties.Resources.DynamicProxy_ProxyTargetDoesNotImplementInterface
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The service implementation to proxy, type '{0}', does not implement the service interface '{1}' that the proxy will implement. Check your Autofac registrations to make sure the service implementation type isn't somehow tied to the service interface..

member.name: P:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Properties.Resources.MultitenantContainer_TenantAlreadyConfigured
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The tenant with ID '{0}' has already been configured. It cannot be reconfigured..

member.name: P:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Properties.Resources.MultitenantServiceImplementationDataProvider_ServiceInterfaceTypeNotInterface
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The string '{0}' resolved to type '{1}' which is not an interface. For multitenancy to work, the service type to host should be the service interface rather than the concrete implementation type. You then register the concrete implementation type as the interface with Autofac, like: builder.RegisterType<ImplementationType>().As<InterfaceType>();.

member.name: P:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Properties.Resources.MultitenantServiceImplementationDataProvider_ServiceInterfaceTypeNotResolvable
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The string '{0}' could not be resolved to a type. Make sure you specify the fully qualified type name, like "Namespace.TypeName, AssemblyName" and not just the type name..

member.name: P:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Properties.Resources.MultitenantServiceImplementationDataProvider_ServiceInterfaceTypeNotServiceContract
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The string '{0}' resolved to type '{1}' which is not marked with the System.ServiceModel.ServiceContractAttribute. For multitenancy to work, the service type to host should be the service contract interface. You then register the concrete implementation type as the interface with Autofac, like: builder.RegisterType<ImplementationType>().As<InterfaceType>();.

member.name: T:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.AutofacHostFactory
member.summary: Base class for factories that create service host instances for WCF.

remarks.para: This implementation of the Autofac service host factory allows you to change the strategy by which service implementations are resolved. You do this by setting the with a strategy implementation.

If is a new instance of will be used. This is different behavior than the standard Autofac service host factory. If you want to use the standard behavior (which is not multitenant), set to be an instance of .

For multitenancy to work properly, you must set the
to be a .
You may configure additional behaviors or other aspects of generated service instances by setting the . If this value is not , generated host instances will be run through that action.

The of type that contains the base addresses for the service hosted.
member.returns: A with specific base addresses.

remarks.para: If is a new instance of will be used. This is different behavior than the standard Autofac service host factory. If you want to use the standard behavior (which is not multitenant), set to be an instance of .

member.param: Data about which service type to host and how to resolve the implementation type.
The base addresses.
member.returns: A with specific base addresses.

remarks.para: If is not , the new service host instance is run through the configuration action prior to being returned. This allows you to programmatically configure behaviors or other aspects of the host.

member.name: T:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.AutofacInstanceContext
member.summary: Manages instance lifetimes using an Autofac inner container.

remarks.para: This instance context extension creates a child lifetime scope based on a scope provided - generally a tenant-specific lifetime scope - and resolves service instances from that child scope.
When this instance context is disposed, the lifetime scope it creates (which contains the resolved service instance) is also disposed.

member.name: T:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.DynamicProxy.IgnoreAttributeInterfaceProxyInstanceContributor
member.summary: Code generator that ignores type-level non-inherited attributes.

remarks.para: The default behavior of is to generate a type definition that copies over all of the non-inherited attributes from the target interface. This includes the that would be copied over from service interfaces. Unfortunately, WCF doesn't allow a type marked with to also implement an interface marked with . This code generator does everything that does except it doesn't copy over type-level non-inherited attributes.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.DynamicProxy.IgnoreAttributeInterfaceProxyInstanceContributor.#ctor(System.Type,System.String,System.Type[])
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Type of the target to proxy.
The proxy generator ID.
The additional interfaces to implement.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.DynamicProxy.IgnoreAttributeInterfaceProxyInstanceContributor.Generate(Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.Emitters.ClassEmitter,Castle.DynamicProxy.ProxyGenerationOptions)
member.summary: Generates the class defined by the provided class emitter.
member.param: The being used to build the target type.
The options to use during proxy generation.

remarks.para:
This overridden version of the method does everything that the base
method does but it skips the part where it checks for non-inherited attributes and copies them over from the proxy target.

member.name: T:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.DynamicProxy.ServiceHostInterfaceProxyGenerator
member.summary: Interface proxy generator that builds a proxy that has a default constructor and does not copy over non-inherited type attributes.

remarks.para: The standard builds a proxy object that has no default constructor. While a default constructor is not useful from an actual proxying standpoint, the WCF service host will only host object types that have default constructors. As such, if we want to start the service host with a proxy type, the proxy type has to have a default constructor.

Also, the standard generates a type that copies all of the non-inherited attributes over from the target interface, which causes WCF to choke on the , which is already on the service contract interface. This generator overrides
to change the set of code generating contributors to make a slimmer proxy that WCF hosting will accept.

member.name: F:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.DynamicProxy.ServiceHostInterfaceProxyGenerator._metadataBuddyType
member.summary: Holds the metadata buddy class type for the service interface.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.DynamicProxy.ServiceHostInterfaceProxyGenerator.#ctor(Castle.DynamicProxy.ModuleScope,System.Type)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The scope of the module being built.
The interface that will be proxied.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.DynamicProxy.ServiceHostInterfaceProxyGenerator.CreateTypeAttributes(Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.Emitters.ClassEmitter)
member.summary: Adds custom attributes to the generated type.
member.param: The class emitter.

remarks.para: This override calls the base functionality and then uses the metadata buddy class (as specified by a on the service interface) to copy over class-level attributes to the dynamic hosting proxy.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.DynamicProxy.ServiceHostInterfaceProxyGenerator.GetTypeImplementerMapping(System.Type[],System.Type,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Castle.DynamicProxy.Contributors.ITypeContributor}@,Castle.DynamicProxy.Generators.INamingScope)
member.summary: Gets the contributors for generating the type definition.
member.param: Additional interfaces to implement.
The target type for the proxy.
The list of contributors that will be used to generate the type.
The proxy type naming scope.
member.returns: The list of types being implemented.

remarks.para: This version of the method basically does the same thing as the original/base implementation but with these key differences:

item.description: The original version of the method looks at the to see if there are any mixins to be added to the generated proxy. There is no need for mixin support in WCF service hosting so mixins aren't even checked for and won't be added.

The original version of the method goes through each of the additional interfaces that the are to be implemented, checks them against collisions with mixin definitions, and adds type mappings for the additional interfaces. The only interface that needs to be implemented for the WCF hosting proxy is the service interface, so all of that additional interface checking is skipped.

The original version of the method uses the
as the code generator for the proxy type. Unfortunately, that contributor copies over all non-inherited attributes on the interface including the . The concrete proxy type can't have that attribute because the interface already has it, so WCF hosting dies. This version of the method uses the which does not copy over non-inherited attributes.

member.summary: Proxy builder that has an additional method to create proxies usable in WCF multitenant hosting.

remarks.para:
The primary point of interest in this builder type is the
method, which is used to create an interface proxy type that is hostable by WCF.

member.summary: Validates that the target type to proxy is visible and not generic.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.DynamicProxy.ServiceHostProxyBuilder.CreateWcfProxyType(System.Type)
member.summary: Creates an interface proxy type that can be used by the WCF host.
member.param: The service interface to proxy.
member.returns: A that is a proxy for the interface specified by that will be able to be hosted by WCF.

remarks.para:
This proxy type creation method uses the
to create the service host proxy type. As this is a very specialized proxy type, it does not take options like other proxy types.

member.name: T:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.DynamicProxy.ServiceHostProxyGenerator
member.summary: Proxy generator used in multitenant service hosting.

remarks.para: The WCF service host has very specific requirements around the object type that you pass in when you call .
If you have a type that has a on it and it implements an interface that has on it, the WCF service host complains that you can't have two different service contracts.

The proxy generator uses a to build the proxy types. This is specifically interesting in the
method, which uses some special overrides and additions in the builder.

The builder, when called through , generates proxy types that ignore non-inherited attributes on the service interface (e.g., ) so when the proxy type is generated, it doesn't bring over anything that will cause WCF host initialization to fail or get confused.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.DynamicProxy.ServiceHostProxyGenerator.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.para: The proxy generator uses a to build the proxy types.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.DynamicProxy.ServiceHostProxyGenerator.CreateWcfProxy(System.Type,System.Object)
member.summary: Creates a proxy object that can be used by the WCF service host.
member.param: The WCF service interface for service implementations.
The target of the proxy object that will receive the actual calls.
member.returns: An object that implements the interface and proxies calls to the .

remarks.para: When initializing the service host, call this method with a dummy object, just to create the dynamic proxy type for the first time and get the service host up and running. Subsequent proxies for that interface should have a valid target implementation type to which service calls will be proxied.

member.summary: Creates the WCF service interface proxy type or retrieves it from cache.
member.param: The interface type that will be proxied.
member.returns: A generated proxy type that can be used to proxy calls to actual service implementations.

member.summary: Proxy generator used to create proxy types that will be substituted in during service hosting.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.MultitenantServiceImplementationDataProvider.GetServiceImplementationData(System.String)
member.summary: Gets data about a service implementation.
member.param: The constructor string passed in to the service host factory that is used to determine which type to host/use as a service implementation.
member.returns: A object containing information about which type to use in the service host and how to resolve the implementation.

remarks.para: This method returns a dynamic proxy object as the type to host and resolves the implementation type as a dynamic proxy that proxies to a tenant-specific implementation. This is necessary since WCF will only allow hosting of concrete classes and we need it to, effectively, host an 'interface' - in this case, a dynamic proxy type rather than an actual implementation type.

member.exception: Thrown if does not resolve into a known type, resolves to a type that is not an interface, or the interface it resolves to is not marked with a .

member.name: T:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.ServiceMetadataTypeAttribute
member.summary: Specifies the metadata class to associate with a service implementation.

remarks.para: When hosting a service in a multitenant environment using and the dynamic proxy generation that occurs therein, you can't really mark your "service implementation class" with metadata attributes like the . Also, since many of these attributes require you to mark a class rather than the service interface, there's no way to otherwise specify them.

This attribute works similar to the System.ComponentModel.DataAnnotations.MetadataTypeAttribute and allows you to mark a service interface such that the generated dynamic proxy class will use a "metadata buddy class" to retrieve various attributes that should be applied during generation.

Mark your service interface with one of these attributes, then create an empty class with the (or whatever) associated with it. The dynamic proxy generation will copy these attributes, thus allowing you to still make use of service metadata info.

This is particularly handy when choosing to specify a service name. Since WCF usually infers the service name (which is also the name of the service element in configuration that it uses to set up the service host) from the type of the implementation, a dynamic proxy implementation results in service names like Castle.Proxies.IMyServiceProxy_1. To manually specify the name, you use the property, which can be associated with a service metadata buddy class.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.ServiceMetadataTypeAttribute.#ctor(System.Type)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The metadata class type for specifying service metadata.

member.name: P:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.ServiceMetadataTypeAttribute.MetadataClassType
member.summary: Gets the metadata class type.
member.value: A indicating the class to be used to gather metadata for the service implementation proxy.

member.name: T:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.SimpleServiceImplementationDataProvider
member.summary: Simple resolver for WCF service implementations. Allows for single-tenant handling of named or typed services. Does not support multitenancy.

remarks.para: The behavior of this resolver is the same as the original WCF integration Autofac host factory where named or typed services are allowed and multitenancy is not supported.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.SimpleServiceImplementationDataProvider.GetServiceImplementationData(System.String)
member.summary: Gets data about a service implementation.
member.param: The constructor string passed in to the service host factory that is used to determine which type to host/use as a service implementation.
member.returns: A object containing information about which type to use in the service host and which type to use to resolve the implementation.

remarks.para: This resolver takes the constructor string stored in the .svc file and resolves a matching typed service from the root application container. That resolved type is used both for the service host as well as the implementation type.

member.exception: Thrown if the is ; or if the service indicated by is not registered with the .

member.name: T:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.OperationContextTenantIdentificationStrategy
member.summary: An implementation that gets the tenant ID from a attached to the current .

remarks.para: Use this if you are using the as the mechanism for tracking which tenant a given operation is running under.

For example, you could use an that gets the tenant ID from an incoming header and adds a
to the current with the tenant ID value. Then you could register this provider as the mechanism for determining the tenant ID when resolving multitenant dependencies.
The does exactly that - adds the tenant ID to outbound messages on the client and parses them on the service side. For a usage example, see

member.summary: Attempts to identify the tenant from the current operation context.
member.param: The current tenant identifier.
member.returns: if the tenant could be identified; if not.

remarks.para:
The will be the value from the first
found on the current , or if there is no extension found on the operation context.

member.name: T:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Wcf.TenantPropagationBehavior`1
member.summary: Behavior for WCF clients and service hosts that is used to propagate tenant ID from client to service.
member.typeparam: The type of the tenant ID to propagate. Must be nullable and serializable so it can be added to a message header.

remarks.para:
This behavior applies the to WCF clients and service hosts to automatically get the tenant ID on the WCF client end, add the ID to a header on the outbound message, and have the tenant ID read from headers on the service side and added to the operation context in an . This allows you, on the service side, to use the
as your registered .

example.para: In the following examples, the tenant ID is a , so the in the examples corresponds. In your application, your tenant ID may be a nullable GUID or some other object, so you'd need to update accordingly. That would mean passing a different type as and implementing a custom that parses the appropriate tenant ID from the execution context.
The following snippet shows what registration of this behavior might look like in an ASP.NET application that consumes WCF services.

Note that much of the above code is the standard ASP.NET application wireup with Autofac. The important part is when you register the service client - it needs to have a attached to it that can get the container provider from the current application.
The following snippet shows what registration of this behavior looks like in a WCF application hosted in IIS:

Note that it is also very similar to standard wireup with Autofac WCF integration, just that you use the multitenant WCF host, a multitenant container, and a behavior to get the tenant ID from the operation context.

member.name: T:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Web.RequestParameterTenantIdentificationStrategy
member.summary: Uses the specified request parameter (query string, post data etc.) to identify the current tenant.

remarks.para: One of many potential ways to get the tenant from a request context, this strategy reads from the incoming request parameters collection (e.g., querystring, form, etc.) and determines the tenant from there.

Note that, due to the request parameter collection being easily modified by an outside party (simply change the querystring!), this is inherently an insecure mechanism for tenant determination. It is helpful for simple web site creation and debugging but is not recommended for production.

member.name: M:AutofacContrib.Multitenant.Web.RequestParameterTenantIdentificationStrategy.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Create a new for the specified parameter name.
member.param: The request parameter name that holds the tenant identifier.

member.returns: if the tenant could be identified; if not.
